marker.ph:
{"html": "

Flutter's core team is working on supporting a feature that is super necessary in modern applications: Google Maps. But it isn't here yet. For the time being, it's easy to fake Google Maps in your app.

Hopefully, by the time you're reading this, Google Maps support will be implemented and this will be irrelevant.

What We're Building

I'll walk you through building this map demo app that I made.

Google Static Maps API

Google Static Maps simply serves up images. While not ideal, because it's not interactive, it can give you a temporary solution and its easy.

My favorite thing about the API is how easy it is use. The url that you create renders the image on the fly. You don't have to make a request with a body and a method and headers. The url that you create to make the request is the url you render.

In other words, on the web you would use Static Maps like this:

<img scr='https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/staticmap?center=37.0902%2C-95.7192&zoom=4&size=600x400&API_KEY' />

Which renders this on the fly.

This is pretty awesome. You don't even have to fiddle with asynchronous programming. There's no trying and catching of errors. You simply construct your URL and use it as if it's an image.

Static Maps in Flutter

The tl;dr steps you need to take:

  1. Get a Static Maps Api Key
  2. Construct your URL using user input or location.
  3. Render the map in the Flutter.

First, Get an API Key

Luckily, Google has made this extremely easy on us. Just go to Google Maps Api page, select 'Get Started', and then select 'Google Static Maps Api'. Follow the steps from there.

Build Your Flutter App

Actually rendering a map in Flutter is dead simple. Just use the Image widget.

import 'package:flutter/material.dart';


class StaticMap extends StatelessWidget {
  @override
  Widget build(BuildContext context) {
    return new Container(
      child: new Image.network('https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/staticmap?center=37.0902%2C-95.7192&zoom=4&size=600x400&YOUR_API_KEY'),
    );
  }
}

This renders a map of the United States.

If you already know how about building URI's, Static Maps API, and you're pretty comfortable with Flutter, you should stop reading now. That's all there is to rendering a static map in Flutter.

But this isn't entirely useful. We probably want to render a map based on a users location, and possibly provide a marker based on some input or data.

The best way to build the URL is with the dart:uri library. This library will allow us to build a URI by passing variables.

Build Your URL Constructor

Warning: I don't know the difference between a URI and a URL, but I'll be using the terms interchangably.

In order to make any sort of real us of Static Maps, you're going to want to build URLs dynamically, not use hardcoded URLs. First lets take a look at what information we need for the static map, and the format expectation.

This is what you'll need to consider when implementing your URI builder. (Note: Query params are seperated by &##x26;)

  • A base url + the static maps api path: https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/staticmap?

  • Required query params:

    • size: size in pixels passed in as a string size={horizontal_value_pixels}x{vertical_value_pixels}
    • zoom: an integer (between 0 (to view Earth) and 20 (down to Building views)). zoom=6
    • center: either a pair of coordinates {latitude,longitude} or a string address center="moscone center, san francisco, CA".
    • Note: Zoom and center are only required if there are no markers.

    This is a totally valid map URL:

    https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/staticmap?size=600X400&zoom=6&##xA2;er="moscone center, san francisco, CA"&API_KEY

  • Optional Query Parameters

    • maptype: The visual style of the map. roadmap, satelite, hybrid, terrain.
    • markers: where to display markers on the map. Covered below.
    • path: provides connected points on the map. Covered below.

Note: there are more optional params, but these are the ones that I find useful. All Params

Markers &##x26; Path

The markers and path parameters give you a bit of customization options. For the purpose of this Flutter demo, we'll take a look at the basics.

Markers and paths are similar in format, in the fact that you separate the entire markers section of the URL with &##x26;s.

However, you can have multiple markers, as well as style properties. Within the markers section, separate the markers with |.

For example ...&##x26;markers=45.678,43.899|45.987,42.345&##x26;...

That will give you two markers. You can also add style decisions, such as marker color, by passing in parameters, also seperated by |.

Using the example above: ...&##x26;markers=color:blue|45.678,43.899|45.987,42.345&##x26;...

Paths work similarly: path=color:0x0000ff|40.737102,-73.990318|40.749825,-73.987963|40.752946,-73.987384|40.755823,-73.986397.

That will draw a path between 3 locations as a red line. These paths do not follow roads.

Dart Uri Library

The Dart Uri Library is super handy in this situation because we can build formatted Static Map Uris based on device location or user input.

Suppose we want this result:

https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/staticmap?size=600x400&markers=color:red|45.512,-122.67|46.512,-122.67&AIzaSyCzxj6UFfx8uvDaaE9OSSPkjJXdou3jD9I

We can use the library to build that uri with no worry about formatting.

First, establish a UriBuilder class, and add the information to build the base URL without the parameters.

    // the locations, wdth and height depend on the users device, don't worry about it yet.
  String _buildUrl(List<Location> locations, int width, int height) {
    var finalUri = new UriBuilder()
      ..scheme = 'https'
      ..host = 'maps.googleapis.com'
      ..port = 443
      ..path = '/maps/api/staticmap';
      
  // ... continued below

Now, with every request we make, we'll have this:

https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/staticmap?

From here, your implementation may be different depending on your needs. For my needs, I wanted to render a default map if there was no relevant location in the work order, but if there was location information, load up the proper map. This is the code:

    // continue from previous code block
    
    // Our state will always have a location, which is the default location if no location is passed in.
    // If there aren't multiple locations, then there are no markers.
    // With no markers, you must specify `center`, `zoom`.
    if (locations.length == 1) {
          finalUri.queryParameters = {
            'center': '${locations[0].latitude},${locations[0].longitude}',
            'zoom': defaultZoomLevel.toString(),
            'size': '${width ?? defaultWidth}x${height ?? defaultHeight}',
            '$googleMapsApiKey': ''
          };
     // Otherwise, there is location data passed in.
     // If there are multiple locations, then we need to display some markers.
     
    } else {
          List<String> markers = new List();
          locations.forEach((location) {
            num lat = location.latitude;
            num lng = location.longitude;
            String marker = '$lat,$lng';
            markers.add(marker);
          });
          String markersString = markers.join('|');
          finalUri.queryParameters = {
            'markers': markersString,
            'size': '${width ?? defaultWidth}x${height ?? defaultHeight}',
            '$googleMapsApiKey': ''
          };
        }
    
        return finalUri.toString();
      }

That's our uri building function. It's pretty simple! Now we just need to be able to pass it user information.

Note: I also have default variables set to handle lack of information from the user.

Getting the device location

"...}
{"title": "Faking Google Maps in a Flutter App"...}
